column3:
~0 on this, uint256S takes `0x` prefixes for historical reasons but the input is not really a number, it's a hash, a binary blob.
Ever since the split with `arith_uint256`, `uint256` is misnamed and simply a 256-bit blob.
(but at the time, the rename from `uint256` to `blob256` wasn't accepted)

No strong opinion but I don't think this makes anything any clearer.
I actually didn't know that `0x` was possible. ~0 on this as well.
Closing for now due to controversy
